paper_title: Fibrosis and MAGNIFI-CD Activity Index at Magnetic Resonance Imaging to Predict Treatment Outcome in Perianal Fistulizing Crohn’s Disease Patients

correlations.context: Predictive accuracy for long-term clinical closure
Predictive accuracy for long-term clinical closure

estimated_points.description: Closed fistulas clustered at low MAGNIFI-CD scores (median 0, IQR 0-5)
Open fistulas clustered at higher MAGNIFI-CD scores (median 16, IQR 10-20)

row_summaries: Number of tracts: 0=None, 1=Single unbranched, 2=Complex (Weight=3)
Hyperintensity on post-contrast T1-weighted images: 0=Absent/mild, 1=Pronounced (Weight=2)
Dominant feature: 0=Fibrous, 1=Granulation tissue, 2=Fluid/pus
Fistula length: 0=<2.5 cm, 1=2.5–5 cm, 2=>5 cm (Weight=2)
Extension: 0=Absent, 1=Horseshoe, 2=Infralevatoric/supralevatoric (Weight=2)
Inflammatory mass: 0=Absent, 1=Focal, 2=Diffuse, 3=Collections small, 4=Collections medium, 5=Collections large (Weight=1)
Total MAGNIFI-CD Range: 0-25
Pre-treatment MRI characteristics [n=48]
Degree of fibrosis <40%: 38 [79%]
MAGNIFI-CD: 16 [9–20]
Degree of fibrosis: 0.77 [0.64–0.89]
MAGNIFI-CD index: 0.88 [0.79–0.93]

component_mappings.notes: VAI includes T2 hyperintensity; MAGNIFI-CD includes hyperintensity on post-contrast T1 (Weight=2)
Both assess presence of abscess/inflammatory collections

fibrosis_definition: Fibrosis was defined as an absence of hyperintensity on all sequences.
fibrosis_scoring_method: The item degree of fibrosis was composed for the current study... It was evaluated by estimating the volume of the fistula tract that consisted of fibrosis on a T2-weighted sequence without fat suppression... No actual fistula volumes were measured.
key_findings: The study evaluates MAGNIFI-CD index and a novel 'degree of fibrosis' score (0-100%) for predicting long-term clinical closure.
No direct comparison or crosswalk between Van Assche Index (VAI) and MAGNIFI-CD is provided.
The MAGNIFI-CD index at post-treatment MRI had high accuracy (AUC 0.95) for predicting long-term closure.
A cut-off point of MAGNIFI-CD index ≤6 predicts long-term clinical closure with 91% specificity and 87% sensitivity.
A completely fibrotic tract (100% fibrosis) at post-treatment MRI was associated with long-term clinical closure in all 14 patients.
The degree of fibrosis (0-100%) had an AUC of 0.90 for predicting long-term closure.
Interobserver agreement for the MAGNIFI-CD index was 'almost perfect' (ICC 0.88).
The study includes separate analyses for anti-TNF and surgical closure treatment groups.
limitations: No direct paired VAI and MAGNIFI-CD scores are reported.
The study focuses on MAGNIFI-CD and a novel fibrosis score, not on VAI.
The sample size is relatively small (n=50).
Partially retrospective design with different intervals between treatment and post-treatment MRI.
raw_evidence: This study evaluated the predictive value of degree of fibrosis and disease activity (MAGNIFI-CD index) at MRI for long-term clinical closure of Crohn’s perianal fistulas.
Two radiologists scored the degree of fibrosis and MAGNIFI-CD index at pre- and post-treatment MRI.
Median MAGNIFI-CD index at post-treatment MRI was 0 [IQR 0–5] in 25 patients with long-term clinical closure and 16 [IQR 10-20] in 25 patients without.

ROC analysis shows an AUC of 0.95 [95% CI: 0.89–1.00] accuracy in predicting long-term clinical closure. The Youden threshold to determine long-term clinical closure was a MAGNIFI-CD index of 6, with a 91% specificity and 87% sensitivity.
All 14 patients who had a 100% fibrotic fistula at their post-treatment MRI showed long-term clinical closure.
The median pre-treatment MAGNIFI-CD index was 11 [IQR 7–18] in patients who reached long-term clinical closure after their treatment and 19 [IQR 15–23] in patients who did not.
The MAGNIFI-CD index in the anti-TNF group with a closed fistula at long-term clinical follow-up had a median of 5 [IQR 3–5], while in the surgical closure group this was 0 [IQR 0–2].
For the MAGNIFI-CD index as a whole this was ‘almost perfect’ [ICC 0.88].
The item degree of fibrosis was composed for the current study to gain insight into the effect of a partially fibrotic tract on long-term outcomes and has not been evaluated previously.
Fibrosis was defined as an absence of hyperintensity on all sequences.
Table 1 shows the scoring items and calculation of the MAGNIFI-CD index.

The degree of fibrosis was assessed on all 50 scans [28 anti-TNF and 22 surgical closure] and the MAGNIFI-CD index on the 46 scans [25 anti-TNF and 21 surgical closure] which had a post-contrast sequence.

paper_title: Radiological outcomes in perianal fistulizing Crohn’s disease: A systematic review and meta-analysis

row_summaries: Bell et al. (2003): 7 patients, 3M/4F, age 39, 7 infliximab induction, no maintenance
Van Assche et al. (2003): two-part study, 8 patients then 7 patients, infliximab
Tougeron et al. (2009): 26 patients, infliximab
Ng et al. (2009): 26 patients, 10M/16F, 19 infliximab/7 adalimumab
Savoye-Collet et al. (2011): 20 patients, 6M/14F, age 34, 10 infliximab/10 adalimumab
Karmiris et al. (2011): 59 patients, 22M/37F, age 23, all infliximab
Horsthius et al. (2011): 16 patients, 9M/7F, age 34, 16 infliximab induction, no maintenance
Tozer et al. (2012): 41 patients, 16M/25F, age 36, 32 infliximab/9 adalimumab induction, 25 infliximab/16 adalimumab maintenance
Thomassin et al. (2017): 49 patients, 28M/21F, age 33, 43 infliximab/6 adalimumab
Van Assche et al. (2003) part 1: 6 weeks clinical/MRI, 4/8 remission, 1/8 response, 3/8 no response, 0/8 healing, 2/8 improved, 6/8 no response, OR 0.030 (0.00-0.56)
Van Assche et al. (2003) part 2: 10 weeks clinical/MRI, 4/7 remission, 2/7 response, 1/7 no response, 0/7 healing, 6/7 improved, 1/7 no response
Tougeron et al. (2009): 8-12 weeks clinical, 13/26 remission
Karmiris et al. (2011): 11 weeks MRI, 3/29 healing
Horsthius et al. (2011): 12 weeks clinical/MRI, 6/16 remission, 1/16 response, 9/16 no response, 1/16 healing, OR 0.17 (0.030-0.90)
Bell et al. (2003): 14 weeks, 4/7 remission, 1/7 response, 2/7 no response, 2/7 healing, 3/7 improved, 2/7 no response, OR 0.30 (0.030-2.76)
Van Assche et al. (2003): 46 weeks MRI, 2/6 healing, 1/7 improved, 3/6 no response
Tougeron et al. (2009): 255 weeks clinical, 74 weeks MRI, 11/16 remission, 2/14 healing, OR 0.45 (0.050-4.21)
Ng et al. (2009): 52 weeks clinical, 72 weeks MRI, 12/26 remission, 13/26 response, 1/26 no response, 6/20 healing, 13/20 improved, 1/20 no response, OR 0.50 (0.15-1.71)
Savoye-Collet et al. (2011): 52 weeks, 7/20 remission, 8/20 response, 5/20 no response, 2/20 healing, 15/20 improved, 3/20 no response, OR 0.21 (0.040-1.16)
Karmiris et al. (2011): 36 weeks clinical, 94.5 weeks MRI, 24/59 remission, 21/59 response, 14/59 no response, 1/13 healing, OR 0.12 (0.010-1.00)
Tozer et al. (2012): 156 weeks, 4/19 remission, 7/19 response, 7/19 no response, 6/19 healing, 4/19 improved, 9/19 no response, OR 1.73 (0.40-7.51)
Thomassin et al. (2017): 160 weeks clinical, >104 weeks MRI, 26/49 remission, 10/49 response, 13/49 no response, 16/49 healing, OR 0.43 (0.19-0.96)

conversion_statements: A universally accepted grading system for pfCD is therefore yet to be developed.
key_findings: This is a systematic review of 9 studies (259 patients) reporting MRI outcomes in perianal fistulizing Crohn's disease treated with anti-TNFα therapy.
The van Assche score was assessed in seven papers, with conflicting findings.
There remains conflicting data regarding the significance of the van Assche score, particularly in real-world studies, as seen in our review.
No direct mention of MAGNIFI-CD scoring system found in this paper.
The paper discusses heterogeneity in definitions of radiological and clinical outcomes.
The odds ratio of MRI healing versus clinical healing was 0.10 (95% CI, 0.02-0.39) in the short term and 0.43 (95% CI, 0.26-0.71) in the long term.
limitations: No direct comparison between VAI and MAGNIFI-CD found.
No paired patient scores for both indices found.
No correlation coefficients between scoring systems reported.
No scatterplots showing VAI vs MAGNIFI-CD found.
raw_evidence: Composite scores, such as the van Assche score, have been proposed, incorporating anatomical (number of tracts, location, presence/absence of levatoric extension) and inflammatory features (degree of T2 hyperintensity, presence/absence of collections, rectal wall involvement) as a marker of disease severity.
The van Assche score was assessed in seven papers, with conflicting findings.
There remains conflicting data regarding the significance of the van Assche score, particularly in real-world studies, as seen in our review.
A universally accepted grading system for pfCD is therefore yet to be developed.
The odds ratio of MRI healing versus clinical in the short term was 0.10 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.02-0.39) and in the long term was 0.43 (95% CI, 0.26-0.71).
Clinical healing is more common than radiological healing, by a factor of 10 in the short term and 2.33 in the long term.
